content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Tiana Johnson: Well, I was born and raised in Chicago, right here in the city, and I've never really left. I grew up in a tight-knit neighborhood on the South Side, where everyone knew each other. My parents were both pretty driven—my dad had a bachelor's degree and worked in education, while my mom went on to get her graduate degree and had a career in healthcare. We were never super wealthy, but we had a stable life, and I always felt supported. I remember being a pretty quiet kid, more into books than sports, though I did love helping out at my mom's job at the clinic whenever I could. I was always told I had a good head on my shoulders, and I guess that's why I ended up going to college. I studied social work, which led me to my current job at a community center here in Chicago, where I help families navigate resources and support systems. I got married in my late twenties to a guy named Marcus, who's a teacher at a local high school. We have a five-year-old daughter, and life is pretty full these days. There have been challenges, of course—like when we had to move to a new neighborhood after the pandemic, but overall, I feel like I've built a life that's true to who I am.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Tiana Johnson: Yeah, there was definitely a crossroads. I was in my second year of college, studying social work, and I had the chance to do an internship at a nonprofit that provided mental health services to underserved communities. It was intense, but it opened my eyes to the real struggles people face every day. At the same time, I had a friend who was working as a corporate recruiter and encouraged me to consider a more stable, higher-paying job in the private sector. I was torn because I really wanted to make a difference, but I also knew that my family expected me to be financially responsible. In the end, I chose to stick with the nonprofit path because I felt like that was where my heart was. It wasn't easy—there were times when I worried about money and job security—but looking back, I know that decision shaped who I am today. It taught me resilience, empathy, and the importance of staying true to your values, even when the road is uncertain.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Tiana Johnson: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made lightly. I spent a lot of time reflecting on what truly mattered to me—helping others, making an impact in my community, and staying true to the values my parents instilled in me. I remember sitting on my balcony one night, looking out over the city, and just feeling this deep sense of purpose. I knew I couldn't walk away from that. It wasn't just about money or stability—it was about feeling like I was doing something that aligned with who I was. I told myself that if I ever found myself in a place where I was just going through the motions, I'd reevaluate. But so far, I've never looked back.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Tiana Johnson: Absolutely, I think I was really lucky to have people in my life who supported me through that decision. My mom, in particular, was a big influence. She worked in healthcare and saw firsthand the impact that community support could have on people's lives. She reminded me that stability doesn't always mean financial security—it can also mean emotional and moral stability. I also had a mentor at the nonprofit where I interned, a woman named Lila, who had been in similar shoes. She shared her own story of choosing community work over a corporate job and how it had shaped her life. Her encouragement helped me feel less alone in making that choice. I think it's important to have people around you who can offer different perspectives, especially when you're standing at a crossroads. Without them, I might have second-guessed myself more than I did.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Tiana Johnson: Yes, I have a partner and a daughter. I married Marcus when I was 28—he's a high school teacher here in Chicago, and we met through a mutual friend who worked at the community center where I used to volunteer. We got married in a small ceremony at a park on the lakefront, just family and close friends. It was everything I wanted: simple, heartfelt, and surrounded by people who truly mattered. We have a five-year-old daughter named Aisha, and she's the light of our lives. She's already showing so much curiosity and creativity, and I love watching her grow. Marcus and I have our ups and downs, like any couple, but we both value communication and support, which has helped us navigate the challenges of work, parenting, and life in general. Having a family has definitely changed me—it's made me more patient, more present, and more grateful for the little things. I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Going through those interview questions made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by the people and choices I've made. From my childhood in Chicago to the crossroads I faced in college, every step has led me to where I am today—with a family, a purpose, and a deep sense of gratitude. It's amazing how the decisions we make, even when they're difficult, can define who we become. I'm proud of the path I've taken, and I'm even more grateful for the support system that helped me stay grounded along the way.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Tiana Johnson: My immediate family includes my parents, who I'm really close to. My dad, Samuel, is retired now but spent most of his career as a school administrator. He's always been my biggest supporter, even when I was the quiet kid who preferred reading to sports. My mom, Evelyn, is still working part-time in healthcare, and she's the one who taught me the value of compassion and hard work. We talk often, and even though we live in the same city, I make it a point to visit them at least once a month. My relationship with them is built on trust and love—they've always believed in me, even when I wasn't entirely sure of myself. I also have an older brother, Jamal, who lives in Atlanta. We're not as close as I'd like, but we keep in touch, and I know he's proud of the life I've built. Family has always been a cornerstone of who I am, and I'm grateful for the love and guidance they've given me throughout the years.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Tiana Johnson: Absolutely, there are a few friends who have been really important to me over the years. One of them is Lila, the mentor I mentioned earlier—she's more like a sister to me now. We've been through a lot together, and she's always been there to offer advice or just listen when I needed someone. Then there's my friend Maya, who's a nurse at the same clinic where I used to volunteer. We've been friends since college, and even though we've both taken different paths, we still meet up regularly for coffee or to catch up. She's one of the few people who truly understands the challenges of working in community services. Outside of friends, I also have a few coworkers at the community center who have become like family. We all share a common mission, and that bond makes the long hours and sometimes difficult work worth it. I think the people in my life—friends, mentors, and coworkers—have played a huge role in shaping who I am today. They've reminded me that no one has to walk this journey alone.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Tiana Johnson: I live in a neighborhood on the West Side of Chicago now, just a few blocks away from the community center where I work. It's a diverse area—there are long-time residents, newer families, and even some artists and small business owners who have made the area their home. It's not perfect, of course. There are challenges, like gentrification pushing out some of the original residents, and the usual struggles with crime and access to resources. But there's also a lot of resilience here. I love walking through the streets, seeing the murals on the walls, the community gardens, and the little shops that have been around for decades. It feels like a place that's still figuring out its identity, but in a way that's hopeful. I chose to live here because I wanted to be close to the people I serve, and also because I believe in the potential of this neighborhood. It's not always easy, but I feel like I'm part of something bigger here—something that matters.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Tiana Johnson: I would say I feel safe here, but it's not always straightforward. There are parts of the neighborhood where I'm cautious, especially after dark, but I've learned to be aware without letting fear take over. I know the community well, and I've built relationships with neighbors who look out for one another. There's a sense of solidarity here that I really appreciate. I also make sure to take common-sense precautions, like keeping my doors locked and knowing the local police officers who patrol the area. Overall, I feel like I'm in a place where I can contribute positively, and that gives me a sense of security. It's not perfect, but I believe in the strength of this community, and that helps me feel safe in my own skin.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Tiana Johnson: Living here has been a mix of challenges and rewards. On one hand, I love the sense of community and the way people come together to support each other. There are block parties in the summer, local artists painting murals that tell our stories, and neighbors who know your name and your business. It feels like a place where change is happening, but not in a way that erases the soul of the neighborhood. On the other hand, there are days when I feel the weight of the struggles—like when I see a family struggling to afford groceries or when I hear about a local business closing because of rising rents. It's frustrating, but it also fuels my work at the community center. I want to be part of the solution, not just someone who observes the problems. I've learned to find joy in the small victories, like when a client finds stable housing or when a local teen gets into college. It's not always easy, but I believe in this place and the people who call it home. That belief keeps me going.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood made me reflect on how deeply connected I am to the people and places around me. Talking about Marcus, Aisha, my parents, and even my friends like Lila and Maya reminded me of how much support I have in my life. It's easy to get caught up in the challenges of living in a neighborhood that's changing, but when I think about the people I love and the work I do, it all feels meaningful. I'm grateful for the life I've built here, with the people who matter most, and I know that even in the tough moments, I'm not alone.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Tiana Johnson: A typical week for me is pretty varied, but there's a rhythm to it. I start most mornings around 6:30 a.m., making sure my daughter Aisha is up, fed, and ready for school. Marcus usually takes her, so I get a few quiet hours to get ready for work. I work full time at the community center, so my days are pretty packed. Mondays and Wednesdays are usually days when I meet with clients, help them apply for housing assistance, or connect them with local resources. Tuesdays and Thursdays are more about organizing programs—like the after-school tutoring we offer or the food pantry we run in partnership with a local church. Fridays are a bit lighter, and I often use that time to catch up on administrative work or plan for the week ahead. On weekends, I try to spend as much time as possible with Aisha and Marcus. We love going to the park, visiting the zoo, or just having a quiet family dinner. I also make it a point to meet up with Lila or Maya at least once a week for coffee or lunch—it's important to stay connected with the people who have been there for me. Even though my schedule is busy, I try to carve out time for reflection, whether it's reading a book, journaling, or just sitting on my balcony and watching the city wake up. It's not always perfect, but it's a life that feels full, meaningful, and grounded in the things that matter most to me.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Tiana Johnson: I work full time at a community center here in Chicago, and my schedule is pretty consistent throughout the week. I start my day at 8:30 a.m., though I usually get in a little earlier to prepare for the day—sometimes I'll stop by the food pantry to check in or review client files. My role is pretty varied; I work directly with families who are navigating housing, healthcare, or employment challenges. I also help organize workshops on financial literacy, parenting, and mental health. The work can be emotionally demanding, but it's also incredibly rewarding. I've been at the center for almost seven years now, and it's become more than just a job—it's a second home. I love the people I work with, the clients we serve, and the sense of purpose that comes with it. It's not always easy, but I know I'm making a difference, even if it's just one person at a time.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Tiana Johnson: Outside of work and family, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. I've always been a big believer in the power of reflection, so I try to journal every evening before bed. It's not always about big life decisions—it's just about processing the day, expressing gratitude, or even venting about something that's been on my mind. I also have a small garden on my balcony where I grow herbs and a few vegetables. It's a little project that keeps me connected to nature, even in the middle of the city. I find that tending to plants gives me a sense of calm, especially after a long day. And on the weekends, when I'm not spending time with Aisha or meeting up with friends, I like to take long walks through the neighborhood. I enjoy observing the people, the little changes in the streets, and the way the light hits the murals. It's my way of staying present and appreciating the life I've built here.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Tiana Johnson: Well, recently, I've started waking up a bit earlier to get in some quiet time before the day gets going. It's something I've been meaning to do for a while, but with the chaos of work and family, it always slipped through the cracks. Now that Aisha is in school full time and Marcus has a more consistent schedule, I've been able to carve out those extra 30 minutes in the morning. I use that time to meditate, read a chapter of a book, or just sit with my coffee and watch the city come alive. It's been a small but meaningful change—it helps me start the day with more clarity and intention. I also began taking evening walks a few blocks away from home, near a park that's been undergoing some renovations. It's a nice place to clear my head, and I've even started meeting a few neighbors there who are also interested in community projects. It's amazing how small shifts in routine can create new opportunities for connection and growth.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Tiana Johnson: Aisha's typical weekday during the school year starts at 7:30 a.m. with her getting up, brushing her teeth, and having breakfast while I help her get dressed. She goes to school from 8:30 a.m. to 3:00 p.m., and after that, she usually has some time to relax or do her homework before we pick her up. We try to keep her schedule balanced—on Mondays and Wednesdays, she goes to an after-school program at the community center where she does art and plays with other kids. On Tuesdays and Thursdays, she has a sports class at a local gym, which is a lot of fun for her. Fridays are more laid back, and we often go to the park or have a family movie night. I love seeing her get excited about these activities—it's amazing how much she's growing and learning every day. It's also been nice to have Marcus involved in her after-school life; he helps with transportation and sometimes joins her for the sports class. It's a busy schedule, but it's all part of making sure she has a well-rounded childhood.

Going through the interview questions about my neighborhood and daily routines made me reflect on how deeply connected I am to the people and places around me. Talking about the West Side of Chicago, the challenges and rewards of living there, and the rhythm of my days reminded me of how much my work, family, and community shape my life. It's easy to get caught up in the struggles of living in a changing neighborhood, but when I think about the people I love—Marcus, Aisha, my parents, Lila, Maya, and the coworkers at the community center—it all feels meaningful. I'm grateful for the life I've built here, with the people who matter most, and I know that even in the tough moments, I'm not alone. My daily routines, from tending to my garden to journaling before bed, are small ways I stay grounded and present in this life I've chosen. It's not always easy, but it's a life that feels full, purposeful, and deeply connected to the world around me.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Tiana Johnson: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm pretty fortunate. I've always been pretty active, even as a kid—I wasn't into sports, but I loved walking and biking around the neighborhood. I still try to stay on top of that, even with the busy schedule. I do a lot of walking during my workday, whether it's between the community center and local agencies or just exploring the neighborhood. I also make sure to eat well, mostly home-cooked meals with a lot of vegetables and lean proteins. I've been pretty lucky not to have any major health issues, but I do have some mild asthma that I manage with an inhaler, and I've had to be careful with stress over the years. I've learned that when I'm overwhelmed, my body reacts—tight chest, trouble sleeping, that kind of thing. So I've made it a point to take care of my mental health as much as my physical health. I've started seeing a therapist once a month, which has been really helpful in keeping things in balance. I also try to get at least seven hours of sleep every night, and I've found that journaling before bed helps me unwind. Overall, I feel pretty good, and I know that taking care of myself is just as important as taking care of others.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Tiana Johnson: For me, staying healthy is both easy and hard in different ways. On one hand, I have a strong support system—my family, my friends, and even my coworkers at the community center—they all remind me to take breaks, eat well, and not push myself too hard. I also have these little routines, like my morning walks or my evening journaling, that help me stay grounded. But on the other hand, the demands of my job can be overwhelming. There are days when I'm helping families with housing crises or mental health struggles, and it takes a toll on me emotionally. I have to be really intentional about setting boundaries, because it's easy to lose track of time or forget to take care of myself when I'm so focused on helping others. I've learned that staying healthy isn't just about exercise or diet—it's about balance, and that's something I'm still working on every day.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Tiana Johnson: In the past two years, I actually had a pretty significant health experience that I haven't talked about much. About a year ago, I started experiencing some persistent back pain that I initially dismissed as just stress or poor posture from sitting at my desk for long hours. But it got worse over time—especially after a particularly busy month at the community center where I was juggling multiple client cases and organizing a new mental health initiative. I finally went to the doctor, and it turned out I had a herniated disc in my lower back. It was a bit of a wake-up call. I had to take a few weeks off work to recover, which was tough because I felt like I was letting my team down. But it was also a chance to slow down and really focus on my body and mind. I started seeing a physical therapist, and I've been doing regular exercises to strengthen my core and improve my posture. It's been a process, but I'm much better now. That experience made me realize how important it is to listen to my body and not ignore the signs. I've also started incorporating more stretching into my daily routine and making sure I take breaks throughout the day to move around. It's not perfect, but I'm learning to prioritize my health in a way I didn't before.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Tiana Johnson: Honestly, it was a tough time, especially because I felt like I was letting my team and my family down. I was worried about how it would affect my work at the community center and my ability to care for Aisha. There were days when I felt frustrated or even a little defeated, but I also had a lot of support. Marcus took on more of the parenting responsibilities, and my coworkers were incredibly understanding, even helping me with some of my tasks remotely while I was recovering. It also made me realize how much I rely on my health to be there for the people I care about. I don't take that for granted anymore. Now, I make sure to schedule regular check-ups, take breaks throughout the day, and remind myself that taking care of myself isn't selfish—it's necessary. It's helped me become more mindful of how I balance my work, family, and health, and I think that balance is what keeps me grounded and able to show up for the people who need me most.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Tiana Johnson: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—there's been a lot of growth, but also some challenges. On the positive side, I've really grown more in touch with myself, especially after my back injury. That experience forced me to slow down and really listen to what my body and mind needed. I've been more intentional about self-care, which has made a big difference in how I show up for my work and my family. I've also felt a deep sense of gratitude for the people in my life—Marcus, Aisha, my parents, Lila, Maya, and my coworkers. They've all been there for me in different ways, whether it was helping me recover, supporting me through the stress of work, or just being a steady presence. That support has been a huge anchor. At the same time, there have been moments of frustration, especially when I feel like I'm not doing enough for the people I serve at the community center or when I'm struggling to balance everything. But I've learned to be kinder to myself, to recognize that I can't do everything, and that it's okay to ask for help. Overall, I feel more grounded and more in tune with what truly matters to me. I'm still learning, but I feel like I'm on the right path.

Going through the interview questions about my recent changes in routine and health made me reflect on how much I've grown over the past year. It's amazing how small shifts—like waking up earlier, taking evening walks, or even starting therapy—can have such a big impact on my well-being. I used to think that being busy meant I was productive, but now I realize that taking time for myself is just as important as taking care of others. My back injury was a wake-up call, reminding me that I can't pour from an empty cup. I'm learning to listen to my body, set boundaries, and prioritize my health in ways I never did before. It's not always easy, but I'm grateful for the support system around me—Marcus, my coworkers, my friends, and even my parents—they've all helped me stay grounded during this journey. I feel more balanced now, more present in my life, and more connected to the people and routines that truly matter.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Tiana Johnson: Honestly, I've had moments where I've struggled with anxiety, especially during the busiest times at the community center or when I was dealing with the stress of my back injury. There were days when I felt overwhelmed, like I was carrying the weight of the world on my shoulders. I remember one particular time when I was juggling multiple client cases, organizing a new mental health initiative, and trying to keep up with family life. I felt like I was constantly running on empty, and it started to take a toll on my mental health. I didn't want to burden anyone with my struggles, so I tried to push through, but it wasn't sustainable. That's when I realized I needed to take a step back and seek help. I started seeing a therapist, and that made a world of difference. It helped me understand that it's okay to feel anxious or stressed—it doesn't mean I'm weak. It just means I'm human. I've also learned to be more open about my feelings with the people I trust, whether it's Marcus, Lila, or even my coworkers. Talking about it has been a huge relief, and it's helped me feel less alone. I still have days when anxiety creeps in, but I'm learning how to manage it better. I've come to see it not as something to be ashamed of, but as a part of my journey—one that has taught me resilience, self-compassion, and the importance of reaching out when I need support.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Tiana Johnson: For my family, it's been a mix of support and adjustment. Marcus has been my rock through it all—he took on more of the parenting duties when I was recovering from my back injury, and he's always been there to remind me that I'm not alone in this. Aisha, she's been such a blessing. Even though she's only five, she's picked up on my moods and has started asking me if I'm okay. It breaks my heart a little, but it also makes me realize how important it is for me to be present for her, even on my toughest days. My parents have been amazing too—they've checked in on us regularly, offered advice when needed, and just reminded me that I'm not the first person to face these challenges. They've always believed in me, and that gives me strength. It's not been easy, but I feel like we've all grown closer through it. We've learned to communicate more openly, to lean on each other more, and to recognize that it's okay to ask for help. I think that's one of the most important lessons I've taken from this past year—not just for myself, but for my family as a whole.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Tiana Johnson: For me, religion has always been a quiet but steady presence in my life. I was raised Protestant, just like my parents, and even though I don't attend church as regularly as I used to, I still find comfort in my faith. It's not about going through the motions or following rules—it's more about the values that were instilled in me growing up: compassion, humility, and the importance of community. I still pray sometimes, especially when I'm feeling overwhelmed or when I need guidance. I also find peace in knowing that there's something bigger than myself, even if I don't always understand it. My faith has helped me through tough times, like when I was recovering from my back injury or when I felt like I was failing at balancing work and family. It's not the only thing that gets me through, but it's a foundation that I return to when I need grounding. I think of it as a quiet strength, one that doesn't always shout, but is always there when I need it most.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Tiana Johnson: To be honest, I'm not really into social media in the way a lot of people are. I have a Facebook account mostly to stay in touch with family and a few close friends, but I don't spend much time scrolling through feeds or engaging with posts. I find that it can be overwhelming, especially with the constant stream of news and comparisons. I do follow a few local community pages and some organizations that align with my work at the community center, just so I can stay informed about events or initiatives that might benefit the people we serve. I also have an Instagram account, but it's more of a personal thing—I post some photos of my garden or my daughter's artwork, just to share little moments of joy. It's not a big part of my life, but I appreciate the connections it helps maintain. I think I prefer face-to-face interactions or even a phone call over social media, because it feels more real and meaningful to me.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Tiana Johnson: Honestly, I haven't really used social media for support during tough times. I think I prefer turning to the people I know in person—like Marcus, my parents, or even my coworkers at the community center. They've always been there for me, and I find that talking to them face-to-face or over the phone feels more genuine. I know some people find comfort in online communities or support groups, and I respect that. For me, though, it's more about the relationships I've built over the years. I do follow a few local community pages on Facebook, just to stay informed about events or initiatives that might help the people we serve, but I don't see it as a source of emotional support. I think I'm one of those people who needs real, tangible connections rather than virtual ones. That said, I'm not against it—I just haven't found the need for it in my own life.

Going through the interview questions about my health and recent challenges made me reflect on how much I've grown over the past year. It's amazing how something as simple as a back injury could lead to such a profound shift in how I view my well-being. I used to think that being busy meant I was productive, but now I realize that taking time for myself is just as important as taking care of others. My experience with anxiety and the support I received from Marcus, my coworkers, and my therapist has taught me that it's okay to ask for help and that self-care isn't a sign of weakness—it's a necessity. I'm learning to listen to my body, set boundaries, and prioritize my health in ways I never did before. It's not always easy, but I'm grateful for the support system around me and the lessons I've learned along the way.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Tiana Johnson: Over the past year, I've noticed that my stress levels have shifted in interesting ways. There was a time when I felt like I was constantly on edge, especially after my back injury and the demands of my job. But now, I've started to develop healthier coping strategies. I've been more intentional about taking breaks throughout the day, whether it's stepping outside for a few minutes or just closing my eyes and taking a few deep breaths. I've also found that journaling has become a really powerful tool for me—it helps me process my emotions without holding them all in. I've even started practicing mindfulness exercises, like guided meditations, which have helped me stay centered during tough moments. I think the biggest change has been learning to set boundaries—not just at work, but in my personal life as well. I used to feel guilty for saying no or taking time for myself, but now I see it as necessary. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that taking care of my emotional well-being is just as important as taking care of everyone else.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Tiana Johnson: Last month, our biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and Aisha's school supplies and activities. We live in a modest two-bedroom apartment on the West Side, and the rent is about $1,200 a month. Groceries are another big chunk—Marcus and I try to cook most meals at home, but with Aisha's after-school programs and my work schedule, we end up eating out a few times a week. We also have a small car payment, insurance premiums, and some savings set aside for emergencies. One of the things I've been trying to manage better is our monthly budget—using a spreadsheet to track everything from utility bills to entertainment. It's not perfect, but it helps me feel more in control. I also try to set aside a little money each month for something fun, like a family outing or a new book. It's about finding balance, even in the little things.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Tiana Johnson: Last month, our household spent roughly around $3,200, which is pretty close to our usual monthly budget. Rent is definitely the biggest chunk—$1,200 for the apartment. Then groceries come in at about $800, which includes Aisha's snacks for school, meal prepping, and some essentials. We also have around $300 for utilities, and another $300 for car payments and insurance. Aisha's after-school activities and supplies add up to about $200, and we set aside a little over $100 for miscellaneous things like clothing, personal care, and the occasional family outing. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover our needs, and we've been pretty careful with our spending. I've been trying to track everything more closely, and it's helped me feel more in control of our finances. I also make sure to set aside a small emergency fund each month, just in case something unexpected comes up. It's not always easy, but I think we're doing okay.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Tiana Johnson: We rent our home. It's a two-bedroom apartment on the West Side, and while it's not the most spacious, it's comfortable and close to where I work. Renting has always made more sense for us, especially with the way the neighborhood is changing. We've been in the same place for about three years now, and I like the sense of stability it brings. Plus, it's easier to manage with our budget—rent is predictable, and we don't have the added stress of a mortgage payment. I know some people dream of owning a home, but for now, renting feels like the right choice for our family. It gives us flexibility, especially with Aisha's needs and the possibility of moving closer to her school or a new job opportunity down the line.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Tiana Johnson: Over the past year, our bills have had their ups and downs, especially with the seasons and Aisha's school schedule. In the winter, our utility bills went up a bit because we were using more electricity for heating, and we had to replace the furnace filter, which added a few extra dollars. Then, during the spring, we had to pay for a new set of tires for the car, which was unexpected but necessary. Around the holidays, we spent a little more on groceries and gifts for family, and we also had to cover the cost of Aisha's school field trips and supplies. In the summer, when the community center was running more programs, I had to work extra hours, which meant eating out more often and spending a bit more on meals. But overall, I've been careful to track our expenses and adjust as needed. For example, when we noticed that our electricity bill was getting too high, we started using more energy-efficient light bulbs and unplugging devices when they weren't in use. It's been a learning process, but I think we've gotten better at managing our money throughout the year, even with the fluctuations.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how deeply my health, emotional well-being, and personal values are intertwined with the people and routines in my life. It's amazing how something like a back injury could lead to such a profound shift in how I view my own needs and limits. I used to think that being busy meant I was productive, but now I see that taking time for myself is just as important as taking care of others. My experience with anxiety and the support I received from Marcus, my coworkers, and my therapist has taught me that it's okay to ask for help and that self-care isn't a sign of weakness—it's a necessity. I'm learning to listen to my body, set boundaries, and prioritize my health in ways I never did before. It's not always easy, but I'm grateful for the support system around me and the lessons I've learned along the way. I also realize that while I don't rely on social media for emotional support, the real connections I have with family, friends, and coworkers are what truly sustain me. It's these relationships that help me stay grounded, even during the toughest times.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Tiana Johnson: I actually do save, though it's not always in a traditional savings account. I've been trying to be more intentional about setting aside money each month, even if it's just a small amount. I use a separate checking account that I only touch for specific savings goals, like Aisha's college fund or an emergency fund. I also have a habit of saving up for bigger purchases, like the car tires we had to replace last spring—I started putting money aside a few months in advance so I wasn't caught off guard. It's not perfect, and there are definitely months when I slip up or have to dip into savings for something unexpected, but I think it's a start. I've learned that even small, consistent savings can add up over time, and that gives me a sense of control and peace of mind. I also try to be mindful of how I spend, especially on things that aren't essential. It's not always easy, but I believe that saving is a way of showing up for myself and my family, even in small ways.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Tiana Johnson: In the last year, I've been saving for both a rainy day and for bigger goals. The most immediate thing I've been setting aside money for is Aisha's college fund—though I know it's still a long way off, I want to start early so that she has some financial support when the time comes. I also have an emergency fund that I've been slowly building, just in case something unexpected happens, like a medical expense or a sudden repair for the apartment. I've been really conscious of not letting my savings get too low, especially after my back injury reminded me how important it is to have a financial cushion. I also save for things like Aisha's school supplies, field trips, and even small family outings. It's not always easy to stick to a savings plan, especially when life gets busy, but I've found that even small, consistent contributions make a difference. I think of it as a way to show up for my family, not just in the present, but for their future too.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Tiana Johnson: My occupation has always been centered around helping others, which is why I chose social work as my career path. At the community center where I work, my role involves a lot of direct client interaction—helping families navigate housing assistance, connecting them with healthcare resources, and supporting individuals dealing with mental health challenges. One of the most important parts of my job is building trust with the people I serve. It's not just about providing information; it's about listening, understanding their unique circumstances, and empowering them to find solutions. I also organize workshops on topics like financial literacy, parenting, and emotional well-being, which are crucial for the community we serve. The most rewarding part of my work is seeing the impact we make, even in small ways—like when a client finds stable housing or when a teenager gets the support they need to stay in school. It's not always easy, and there are days when the weight of it all feels heavy, but I believe deeply in what I do. It's more than a job—it's a calling, and I'm grateful every day for the opportunity to make a difference in people's lives.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Tiana Johnson: I usually work around 40 hours a week, though it can sometimes stretch a bit longer depending on the needs of the community center and the clients we're serving. My schedule is pretty consistent—Monday through Friday, from 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., but I often stay a little later to wrap up meetings or finish up some paperwork. There are weeks when I'm juggling multiple programs, like the food pantry or mental health workshops, and those can be especially demanding. I also make sure to be available for clients outside of regular hours if needed, whether it's a quick phone call or meeting after work. It's not always easy to keep work and personal life separate, but I've learned to set boundaries, like not checking emails after 7:00 p.m. or making sure I have time for Aisha and Marcus. I think the most important part of my job is showing up—being present for the people who need support, even when it's not convenient. It's a lot, but I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Tiana Johnson: No, I haven't had more than one job. I've been fully committed to my work at the community center since I started there after college. It's been a long-term commitment, and while there have been times when I considered taking on extra shifts or part-time work to supplement our income, I've always prioritized my role there. The work is demanding, but it's also deeply meaningful, and I feel like I'm making a real difference in people's lives. Plus, with Aisha's needs and our family life, I've found that focusing on one job allows me to be more present for my family and my community. I've been lucky to have a stable position here, and I don't see the need to take on more unless something changes in our financial situation. For now, I'm content with the balance I've found.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much I've grown in understanding my own stress, emotional needs, and financial responsibilities. It's been a journey of learning to prioritize my well-being, not just for myself, but for my family too. I used to think that pushing through stress and anxiety was the only way to get things done, but now I see that taking time to breathe, journal, and practice mindfulness is just as important as showing up for my job or my daughter. It's also made me more aware of how my financial decisions impact my peace of mind—tracking our budget, setting aside savings, and being mindful of our expenses have given me a sense of control that I didn't have before. I'm still learning, but I feel more grounded now, more in tune with what truly matters, and more capable of handling life's challenges with grace and resilience.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Tiana Johnson: In total, our household made around $5,200 in the past month. That comes from my full-time salary at the community center, which is about $4,000 after taxes, and Marcus's teaching salary, which is roughly $1,200. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover our needs and even set aside a little for savings. I've been trying to be more mindful of how we spend, especially with the rising costs of everything from groceries to utilities. It's a tight budget, but we've learned to prioritize what matters most—like Aisha's education, our health, and a little something for fun. I know it's not easy, but I feel lucky that we're able to make it work, and I'm grateful for the stability we've built together.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Tiana Johnson: I've been at my current job at the community center for almost seven years now, and it's been a journey of growth, both personally and professionally. The benefits of the job are pretty standard for a nonprofit—health insurance, which is a huge relief, especially after my back injury. We also get paid time off, including vacation days and sick leave, which I've learned to use wisely. I used to think I could push through anything, but now I know that taking time to rest is just as important as showing up for work. The center also offers some professional development opportunities, like workshops on trauma-informed care or leadership training, which have helped me grow in my role. One of the things I appreciate most is the sense of purpose that comes with the job. It's not always easy, and there are days when I feel overwhelmed, but I know that what I do here matters. I've built relationships with my coworkers, clients, and even some of the local organizations we partner with, and that sense of community makes the long hours and sometimes difficult work feel meaningful. I wouldn't trade this job for anything—it's more than just a paycheck; it's a part of who I am.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Tiana Johnson: My relationships at work are really important to me—they feel like an extension of the community I serve. I have a great relationship with my manager, Sarah, who's been a mentor to me since I started. She's supportive, understanding, and always encourages me to grow both in my role and as a person. She's the kind of leader who leads by example, and I admire how she balances compassion with accountability. As for my coworkers, we've built something like a family here. We all share a common mission, and that bond makes the long hours and sometimes difficult work worth it. We check in on each other, celebrate small victories, and support one another through tough times. I think that sense of camaraderie is what keeps me motivated and grounded in this work. It's not just about the job—it's about the people I get to do it with.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Tiana Johnson: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's also a fair amount of flexibility, which I really appreciate. I work Monday through Friday, from 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., but I often stay a little later to wrap up meetings or finish up some paperwork. There are weeks when I'm juggling multiple programs, like the food pantry or mental health workshops, and those can be especially demanding. However, I also have the option to adjust my hours a bit if needed, which helps me balance work with family responsibilities. For example, if Aisha has an early appointment or if Marcus needs to pick her up from school, I can sometimes leave a little earlier or come in a bit later. That flexibility is important because it allows me to be present for my family while still fulfilling my role at the community center. I think the key is that while the core hours are consistent, there's room to adapt when life requires it, and that makes a big difference in how I manage my time and energy.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Tiana Johnson: Overall, I feel pretty stable about my financial situation, though I know it's not without its challenges. We're not wealthy, but we're not struggling either. Between my salary and Marcus's teaching job, we're able to cover our basic needs—rent, groceries, Aisha's school supplies, and even some savings for the future. I've learned to be really mindful of where our money goes, especially with the rising costs of everything from utilities to healthcare. It's not always easy to say no to extra expenses or to resist the urge to splurge, but I've found that tracking our budget and setting small financial goals helps keep us on track. I also feel grateful that I have a job I love, one that gives me purpose and a sense of contribution to my community. That sense of fulfillment makes the financial sacrifices feel more manageable. I know there are days when I worry about the future, especially with Aisha growing up and the cost of college looming, but I also know we're doing our best, and that's something to be proud of.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial stability and work-life balance have shaped my sense of security and purpose. It's amazing how something as simple as tracking our monthly budget or setting aside money for Aisha's future can give me a sense of control in a world that often feels unpredictable. I used to think that being busy meant I was productive, but now I see that managing my finances and work hours with intention is just as important as the work I do at the community center. My job provides more than just a paycheck—it gives me a sense of purpose, and I'm grateful for the flexibility it offers, even when life gets complicated. I've also come to appreciate the small victories in our financial journey, like sticking to our budget or saving for the future, because they remind me that I'm not just surviving—I'm building something meaningful for my family.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Tiana Johnson: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My dad worked as a school administrator, and he was pretty dedicated to his job—he often stayed late or came in early to make sure everything ran smoothly. My mom, on the other hand, worked in healthcare, first as a nurse and later in a management role at a clinic. She was always balancing work with family, and I remember her coming home tired but still making time for us. It wasn't always easy, but they both made it clear that education and hard work were important. I think that's why I ended up choosing a career in social work—because I saw firsthand how their work made a difference in people's lives. It also taught me the value of responsibility and the importance of providing for your family, even when the days are long and the stress is high. I'm grateful for their sacrifices, and I think they set a strong example for me and my brother, Jamal, about what it means to work hard and care for others.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Tiana Johnson: My dad worked as a school administrator, and his most important duties involved managing the day-to-day operations of the school, ensuring that everything from the curriculum to the staff was running smoothly. He was always the one you could count on to resolve conflicts, organize events, and make sure students had the resources they needed. He had a way of making everyone feel seen and valued, which is something I've carried with me in my own work. My mom, on the other hand, started as a nurse and later moved into a management role at a clinic. Her most important activities were providing direct patient care and making sure the clinic had the systems in place to support both the staff and the community. She was incredibly compassionate, and I remember watching her comfort patients who were scared or in pain. She taught me that healthcare isn't just about treating symptoms—it's about treating people with dignity and care. Both of them had demanding jobs, but they always made time for us, and that balance between work and family is something I try to emulate in my own life.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Tiana Johnson: My dad worked for a public school district in Chicago, and my mom worked for a community health clinic in the same neighborhood where we grew up. Both of them were employed by local organizations that served the people around us, which I think is why I felt so connected to community work from a young age. My dad's job was more about administration—he made sure that the school had the resources it needed, from textbooks to staff training, and he was always advocating for students, especially those from low-income families. My mom's job was more hands-on—she started as a nurse, providing direct care to patients, and later moved into a management role where she oversaw the clinic's operations and made sure that the staff had the support they needed. She was really passionate about making healthcare accessible to everyone, no matter their background or financial situation. Both of them made a living through their work, and while they didn't earn a lot, they always made sure we had what we needed. I think their jobs taught me that service to others is one of the most important things you can do with your life, and that's why I chose to go into social work.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Tiana Johnson: A few years from now, I hope I'm still doing the work I love at the community center, but maybe with a little more stability and growth in my role. I'd love to see the programs we've started—like the mental health workshops and the food pantry—expand and reach more people in need. I also hope that Aisha is thriving in school, maybe even showing an interest in helping others, just like I did. I can see her growing into a compassionate, curious young woman who knows the value of community and service. For Marcus and me, I hope we've found a better balance between work and family, maybe even with a little more flexibility in our schedules so we can take more trips or spend more time together. I also hope that we've built up a stronger emergency fund and that we're more prepared for the future, whether that's college for Aisha or unexpected life changes. Most of all, I hope I'm still feeling grounded, grateful, and connected to the people and place that have shaped me. I know life will have its challenges, but I believe in the path I'm on, and I'm excited to see where it leads.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Tiana Johnson: What I value the most in my life is connection—connection with my family, my community, and the people I serve. There's something deeply meaningful about knowing that my work, however small, makes a difference in someone else's life. I value the moments with Aisha when she looks up at me with that curious smile, or when Marcus and I share a quiet laugh after a long day. I value the relationships I've built with my coworkers, clients, and friends, because they remind me that no one has to go through life alone. I also value the sense of purpose that comes with my work, the knowledge that I'm part of something bigger than myself. Even in the hardest moments, I find strength in the love, support, and shared humanity that surround me. I think that's what keeps me grounded—it's not about perfection or wealth, but about showing up for the people and values that truly matter.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how deeply my financial stability, work-life balance, and the support I receive at my job shape my sense of security and purpose. It's amazing how something as simple as tracking our monthly budget or setting aside money for Aisha's future can give me a sense of control in a world that often feels unpredictable. I used to think that being busy meant I was productive, but now I see that managing my finances and work hours with intention is just as important as the work I do at the community center. My job provides more than just a paycheck—it gives me a sense of purpose, and I'm grateful for the flexibility it offers, even when life gets complicated. I've also come to appreciate the small victories in our financial journey, like sticking to our budget or saving for the future, because they remind me that I'm not just surviving—I'm building something meaningful for my family.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection and gratitude. It's amazing how much my life has been shaped by the people, choices, and experiences I've had—from growing up in Chicago with supportive parents, to making the conscious decision to follow my heart into social work, to building a family and finding purpose in my community. I've learned that life isn't always easy, and there are moments when I feel overwhelmed, like when I dealt with my back injury or struggled with anxiety. But it's also those challenges that have taught me resilience, the importance of self-care, and the value of the relationships I've built with my family, friends, and coworkers. I've come to realize that my work at the community center isn't just a job—it's a calling, and it's what gives my life meaning. I'm proud of the path I've taken, and I'm even more grateful for the support system that has helped me stay grounded along the way. This interview has reminded me that while I may not have everything, I have a life that is full, meaningful, and deeply connected to the people and places that matter most to me.
